summary:
I am a post-PhD Argentinian scholar highly committed to reinstating and strengthening Latin America's own cultural memory in order to consolidate knowledge derived from that memory. 

My research agenda embraces an epistemic project in dialogue with all those who have been constructed as others, instead of producing academic knowledge about others. I am passionate about gnoseological and intercultural dialogues between Western culture and Andean culture. 

By articulating critical studies of habitat and the trans/post-disciplinary fiel of decolonial thinking, I build bridges with the Andean cultural heritage, to unveil and understand Western processes of erasure and to learn how to address human and environmental exploitation.

treasury_media.title: The Territory of Our Body: A Conversation on Urban Environments in the Andes and Their Bodies
treasury_media.description: In this chapter, we dialogically intertwine meanings that flow between the Western and the Andean cultural horizons, in urban environments marked by coloniality. Attentive to different ways of establishing community, we evoke elements from the Andean worldview from a decolonial perspective. By opening to the Andean way of understanding and feeling the relationship between the social and the natural, we rehearse answers to social and environmental crises.

profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Researcher

company.name: International Institute of Social Studies (ISS) of Erasmus University Rotterdam

profile_positions.company: International Institute of Social Studies (ISS) of Erasmus University Rotterdam
profile_positions.description: Main tasks: Write grant applications. Develop public seminars and Lecturer at ISS. Write publications. I applied a Marie Curie Individual Fellowships from the European Commission and NWO Veni scheme from the Dutch Research Council. Both applications received very favourable evaluations that exceeded threshold. Evaluators highlighted: innovation in questioning academic discussions, new approaches towards mutual understanding of diversities on the global level, convincing interdisciplinary dialogue, excellent understanding of the state of art including independent thinking and impressive relevant literature, and cutting-edge methods. A proposal theoretically rich, well embedded in relevant networks and communities, societally relevant, engaged with ‘hot topics’ in Dutch academia and committed to addressing social injustices. Despite their merits, the scores obtained did not suffice, given the budgetary resources available for the call.
profile_positions.title: Guest Researcher and Lecturer

company.name: National Scientific and Technical Research Council

profile_positions.description:
This awarded Research Project is called Collective knowledge constructions between different habitat-emergent gnosiologic communities. Situated experience: Rural schools in the margins of the city of San Martín de los Andes, Neuquen Province, North Patagonia. 
Funding source: Posdoctoral scholarships granted by the National Scientific and Technical Research Council (CONICET). Institute: Center of Research and Studies about Culture and Society (CIECS).
profile_positions.title: Post-doctoral Researcher

profile_positions.description:
I worked in the Co-construction of knowledge Research Program at the Centre of Research and Studies about Culture and Society (CIECS-CONICET) supervised by PhD. Paula Peyloubet and composed of  Researchers from different disciplines. 

This Research Program explores the Pluriversal Constructions of Knowledge in Habitat Production Processes to generate social transformations. This approach constitutes the co-built epistemological and methodological perspective and is based on gnoseological articulation across plurality. 

In the context of that trans-disciplinar academic space, I worked on my PhD research and contributed to different Collective research projects:

PhD Project: Decolonial Movements in Andean Patagonia. Thoughts for a conversation based on the territory. Funding source: CONICET Doctoral Fellowship. (FIN DOC 2015-2017). Supervisor: PhD. Paula Peyloubet. Co-Supervisor: PhD. Mariana Ortecho.
 
Collective Project: Recovering of co-constructive processes between different actors in the context of a cognitive pluriversality for the social transformation in the field of habitat. 
Funding source: CONICET. Supervisor: PhD. Paula Peyloubet. Co-Supervisor: PhD. Corina Echavarría.
 
Collective Project: Innovative interactoral design of technological development processes in habitat production as an articulation instrument between State and the different Productive Units in the value chain of the forestry sector. Funding source: National Ministry of Science and Technology. Supervisor: PhD. Paula Peyloubet.
 
Collective Project: Interactoral network of social technology development, linked to the forestry production in the field of habitat.
Funding source: National Ministry of Science and Technology. Supervisor: Paula Peyloubet, PhD.

volunteer_experiences.description: was also appointed coordinator of a transnational program of the Ministry of Science and technology of Argentina, where I am still engaged on policies that connect research and teaching agendas between Argentina and the Netherlands through the Argentinian embassy. The Network is part of the RAICES Program of the Argentinian Ministry of Science, Technology and Innovation.

company.name: Latin American organization in Amsterdam concerned with gendered violence and racial exclusion

volunteer_experiences.description: I co-founded a Latin American organization in Amsterdam concerned with gendered violence and racial exclusion where I encouraged societally relevant activities that allowed me to develop intellectually grounded analysis of contemporary racial/ethnic and gender inequalities in Dutch society.
I co-organise and host academic events on Latin American issues within Dutch institutions.
